description:
How long are users willing to wait for a web page to load?

Page load time is the time it takes to display all the content of a web page in a user's browser after they click on the site.

It is proven that web pages that load faster are perceived as more interesting than those that are slower. (Ramsay, Barbesi and Preece (1998). However, many processes involving a request to a server often take a long time, and exceed the tolerable waiting time of 2 seconds highlighted by (Nah, 2004). In such cases, reducing page load time seems to be technically challenging. 

Fortunately, there is also evidence to suggest that the availability of feedback extends the tolerable waiting time of Web users. Consequently, it is advantageous for browsers or websites to provide users with feedback when there is an expected wait for a page to load. This information not only reduces uncertainty about the wait, but also fills in the wait time so that Web users are less aware of how long the wait is.

references.citation: Nah, F. F. H. (2004). "A study on tolerable waiting time: how long are Web users willing to wait?"Â
references.summary: Web users often face a long waiting time for downloading Web pages. Although various technologies and techniques have been implemented to alleviate the situation and to comfort the impatient users, little research has been done to assess what constitutes an acceptable and tolerable waiting time for Web users. This research reviews the literature on computer response time and users' waiting time for download of Web pages, and assesses Web users' tolerable waiting time in information retrieval. It addresses the following questions through an experimental study: What is the effect of feedback on users' tolerable waiting time? How long are users willing to wait for a Web page to be downloaded before abandoning it? The results from this study suggest that the presence of feedback prolongs Web users' tolerable waiting time and the tolerable waiting time for information retrieval is approximately 2 seconds.
references.name: A study on tolerable waiting time: how long are Web users willing to wait?

references.citation: Ramsay, J., Barbesi, A. and Preece, J., 1998, A psychological investigation of long retrieval times on the world wide web. Interacting with Computer
references.summary: With the increasingly rapid uptake of the World Wide Web, even those pages classed as â€˜the best of the webâ€™ are not immune to large download latencies. This paper investigates whether the latency between requesting a page and receiving it influence user perceptions of the page. The paper describes a study in which users are presented with seven different web pages with delays ranging from 2 s to 2 min, and are then asked to rate the pages on a number of criteria. Predetermined delays were injected into the page loading process. Pages which were retrieved faster were judged significantly more interesting than their slower counterparts. The implications for web page design are discussed.
references.name: A psychological investigation of long retrieval times on the World Wide Web

name: Users can tolerate about 2 seconds for a page to load or more if a feedback is provided

description:
Do you care if a computer says sorry?

Research has found that users spent more time engaging with a system that provided emotional responses than with one providing generic feedback.

Key takeaways:
- Nass demonstrated that users who received flattery from a computer thought the interaction was more pleasant than users who received generic feedback (Nass, 1997).
- Tzeng found that apologetic responses made users feel better about the overall interaction with the system (Tzeng, 2004).

references.citation: Jeng-Yi Tzeng. 2004. Toward a more civilized design: studying the effects of computers that apologize. Int. J. Hum.-Comput. Stud. 61, 3 (September 2004), 319â€“345.
references.summary: While it is difficult to create completely error-free interactions in software design, the issue of how to make users feel better when they encounter errors is critical to the concept of user-centered design. Neilsen argued for offering a slightly apologetic statement before an error message provided by web servers, but the notion of a computer apologizing to its users inevitably triggers a debate about the appropriateness of providing humanized messages to users. To understand how users react to computers' apologies (presented by textual or visual formats), a computer-guessing game was designed to test users' reactions. The game features three treatments (difficulty levels, feedback types, and emotional icons), each having two levels (difficult vs. easy, apologetic feedback vs. non-apologetic feedback, with emotional icons vs. without emotional icons). Two-hundred and sixty nine high school students participated in this study and were randomly assigned to one of eight groups. The results show that while the computers' actual performances still dominated the users' assessments of the program, the computer apologies help to create more desirable psychological experiences for the users, and emotional icons help to improve the aesthetic quality of the program.
references.name: Toward a more civilized design: studying the effects of computers that apologize

references.citation: B.J. Fogg, and C. Nass. â€œSilicon Sycophans: The Effects of Computers That Flatter.â€International Journal of Human-Computer Studies
references.summary: A laboratory experiment examines the claims that (1) humans are susceptible to flattery from computers and (2) the effects of flattery from computers are the same as the effects of flattery from humans. In a cooperative task with a computer, subjects (N=41) received one of three types of feedback from a computer: â€œsincere praiseâ€, â€œflatteryâ€ (insincere praise) or â€œgeneric feedbackâ€. Compared to generic-feedback subjects, flattery subjects reported more positive affect, better performance, more positive evaluations of the interaction and more positive regard for the computer, even though subjects knew that the flattery from the computer was simply non contingent feedback. Subjects in the sincere praise condition responded similarly to those in the flattery condition. The study concludes that the effects of flattery from a computer can produce the same general effects as flattery from humans, as described in the psychology literature. These findings may suggest significant implications for the design of interactive technologies.
references.name: Silicon sycophants: the effects of computers that flatter

description:
Recommendations based on users' eye movements:
- Make labels prominent and easy to navigate
- Position form items in a vertical rather than horizontal list
- Organize visual layouts with white space
- Provide cohesive layouts, since users will build a mental model of your entire page to anticipate the placement of elements before they appear.
- Provide response times of under 100ms; waiting longer than 100ms holds the perception of the user hostage while they wait for something to happen.

references.citation: Hornoff, A.J. and Halverson T., (2003), Cognitive Strategies and Eye Movements for Searching Hierarchical Computer Displays, Proceedings of the ACM Computer Human Interaction Conference. Ft. Lauderdale, FL.
references.summary:
The eye tracking data reveal a number interesting patterns ofÂ visual search behavior which lend themselves to a number of specific design recommendations.People useÂ aÂ hierarchy.Â WhenÂ a useful hierarchy isÂ present, people can focus their attention on one level of the hierarchyÂ at aÂ time.Â They adoptÂ a more systematicÂ search strategy which requires fewer revisits and fewer fixations overall.
DesignÂ recommendation:
Support a multitiered search.Â Do notÂ make users infer the label byÂ studying a few itemsÂ inÂ the group.Â MakeÂ labelsÂ salient.Â MakeÂ it easyÂ to move from label to label with aÂ single eye movement.People can examine multiple items with a single fixation.
DesignÂ recommendation:
Facilitate foveal coverage of more thanÂ oneÂ itemÂ atÂ a time.Â PositionÂ relevant options next to each other, inÂ vertical lists insteadÂ of horizontal lists.Â Left-Â justify keywords.People can navigate white space with single eye movements.Â UsersÂ keepÂ their eyes on relevantÂ screen items, and jump over stretches of white spaceâ€”in this case, up to 8Â° of visual angle between columnsâ€”with single cascades.
DesignÂ recommendation:
Follow the advice ofÂ graphic designers and organize visual layouts with whitespace.Â This studyÂ shows how the human visual system interacts with this design element.People anticipateÂ visual locations.Â People can move their eyes well into an anticipated layout and start â€œsearchingâ€before the layout had even appeared.
Design recommendation:
Provide consistent screen layouts that accommodate anticipatory eye movements to known locations.Â ConsistencyÂ is criticalÂ evenÂ at theÂ level ofÂ visual-perceptual and oculomotor processing.PeopleÂ primeÂ forÂ visual onset.Â When anticipating the appearance of a layout, it appears as if the perceptual-oculomotor system is primed and ready, waiting for the onset.
DesignÂ recommendation:
Design guidelines already recommend providing response times under 100 ms.Perhaps computer responses over 100 ms are annoying not only because they delay task completion and break the illusion of control, but because they effectively hold the perceptual-oculomotor system hostage
references.name: Cognitive Strategies and Eye Movements for Searching Hierarchical Computer Displays

description:
Do breadcrumbs serve as a navigational shortcut?

Breadcrumbs are textual representations of a user's location within the structure of a site, for example, `Home > Furniture > Chairs > Leather Chairs`.

In general, they are used to achieve the following goals:
1. They provide information to the user about where they are in the site
2. They provide shortcut links that allow users to "jump" to previous categories in the sequence without using the Return key.

Key takeaway from studies:
- Less than half of users use the breadcrumb trail to navigate a website.
- Most users reported that they noticed its presence.
- Being taught about the usefulness of breadcrumb trails led to increased usage, as well as faster completion times, fewer page views and minimal use of the back button.

references.citation: Lida, B., Hull, K., and Pilcher, K., (2003), Breadcrumb Navigation: An exploratory study of usage, Usability News 5.1.
references.summary: Just as Hansel and Gretel created a breadcrumb trail to find their path back home, today's internet user often finds a need to get back to a website's previously visited locations; hence, the cyber "breadcrumb trail" was created. This textual representation of where and how information is located within the website allows the user to link to major categories of information along a continuum of sequential order. For example, the breadcrumb path for a leather chair on the Office Max website would be: Home > Furniture > Chairs > Leather Chairs. The location of the navigational path is often prominently placed in the upper left quarter of the website page.
references.name: Breadcrumb Navigation: An exploratory study of usage

references.citation: Hull, S. S. (2004). "Influence of Training and Exposure on the Usage of Breadcrumb Navigation." Usability News, 6(1).
references.summary: Research has reported that breadcrumb navigation improves site efficiency [1, 2]. However, when given a choice, users choose the Back button or navigation bar to navigate rather than the breadcrumb trail [3]. Lida-Rogers & Chaparro (2003) found that participants who used the breadcrumb trail used the Back button less often than users who did not use it; however, no differences were found in other efficiency measures such as total pages visited or total time. Participants may not understand the function of the breadcrumb trail as a navigational tool and understanding itsâ€™ purpose or minimal training might impact usage and/or efficiency [4]. Mere exposure was considered as a means of introducing participants to breadcrumb trails. According to Zajonc (1968), if the function of orienting behavior is eventually to change a novel stimulus into a familiar one, it is also its consequence to render the stimulus object eventually more attractive [5]. Zajonc (1968) states that the mere repeated exposure of the individual to a stimulus object enhances his attitude toward it [5]. Thus, it was hypothesized that mere exposure of the breadcrumb trail would influence participantsâ€™ use of breadcrumb trail navigation during a search task procedure.
references.name: Influence of Training and Exposure on the Usage of Breadcrumb Navigation
